results.headline: A Misunderstood Alien, but Not as Smart as E.T.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Planet 51

results.summary_short: The agreeable but flagrantly unoriginal “Planet 51” belongs to the mix-and-match school of animated moviemaking.

results.headline: Feelings Close to the Surface

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Dear Enemy

results.summary_short: Lee Yoon-ki’s “My Dear Enemy” may confound your expectations of a South Korean film.

results.headline: Probing Psychological Wounds

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Missing Person

results.summary_short: “The Missing Person” is a moody, modern-day noir about derailed lives and suppressed memories.

results.summary_short: In “Mammoth,” when a rich child eats her lunch in New York, a poor boy in the Philippines cries.

results.headline: A Single, Frantic Day

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fix

results.summary_short: “Fix” dashes headlong through Los Angeles with a little charm and a lot of verve.

results.headline: The Past in the Present

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Defamation

results.summary_short: In his disorganized and somewhat annoying “Defamation,” Yoav Shamir, an Israeli filmmaker, tries to stir up a tempest.

results.headline: Steamrolling Over Life’s Obstacles With Family as Cheerleaders

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Blind Side

results.summary_short: “The Blind Side” is a movie made up almost entirely of turning points and yet curiously devoid of drama or suspense.

results.summary_short: Pain, addiction and craziness fuel “Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans.”

results.summary_short: Alexander Sokurov’s “The Sun” looks at the emperor Hirohito in the murk of Japan’s surrender.

results.summary_short: With “Red Cliff,” the director John Woo goes back to his violent roots.

results.headline: What Ails Public Schools? Better Ask, What Doesn’t?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The War on Kids

results.summary_short: A shocking chronicle of institutional dysfunction, “The War on Kids” likens our public school system to prison and its disciplinary methods to fascism.

results.summary_short: “Uncertainty” is a taut, skillful exercise in cinematic clockwork.

results.headline: Delivering Bad News and Truths About War

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Messenger

results.summary_short: Oren Moverman’s sober and satisfying drama shows how the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq have created a fissure in American society.

results.summary_short: “Fantastic Mr. Fox” is in some ways Wes Anderson’s most fully realized and satisfying film.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Turning Green

results.summary_short: “Turning Green” is a whimsical dirty joke of a movie set in a picturesque Irish village.

results.summary_short: To judge by the swelling bosoms spilling out of the frame, the lingerie bill for “Women in Trouble” must have been estimable.

results.summary_short: I know what I have against Roland Emmerich, but what does he have against us?

results.summary_short: Mary Mazzio’s “Ten9Eight: Shoot for the Moon” is a tirelessly inspirational documentary about teenagers competing in a nationwide business contest.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pirate Radio

results.summary_short: Boys will be boys and often at top volume in “Pirate Radio,” Richard Curtis’s fanciful fiction about rebel broadcasters.

results.headline: An Around-the-World Trip to Ask an Age-Old Question

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Oh My God?

results.summary_short: “Oh My God?” is a picturesque but shallow inquiry into the meaning of God.
